fields.headline: Gott's blasphemy
fields.bodyText: Julian Glover (Report, 10 September) incorrectly claims George Holyoake was the last man to be imprisoned for refusing to believe in God. John William Gott died shortly after his fourth term of imprisonment with hard labour, in 1922, during a seaside vacation paid for by The Rationalist Press Association. At the appeal hearing (supported by the National Secular Society), the lord chief justice, Lord Trevethin, had said: "It does not require a person of strong religious feelings to be outraged by a description of Jesus Christ entering Jerusalem 'like a circus clown on the back of two donkeys'. There are other passages in the pamphlets equally offensive to anyone in sympathy with the Christian religion, whether he be a strong Christian or a lukewarm Christian or merely a person sympathising with their ideals. Such a person might be provoked into a breach of the peace." John William Gott is buried without a headstone in Scholemoor Cemetery, Bradford. Gordon Sinclair Barnsley, South Yorkshire
